title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: modernBoot package provides modern resampling methods statistical inference beyond standard parametric assumptions. vignette demonstrates: select appropriate resampling method data Practical examples main function Guidelines interpreting results Best practices publication-quality analyses

previous_headings: Introduction to modernBoot > When to Use Each Method
title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: Use bs_mean() bca_ci() : - data independent identically distributed (IID) - Sample size moderate large (n ≥ 30) - want confidence intervals mean Example: Bootstrap CI mean height {r bootstrap-example} # Simulate height measurements (cm) heights <- c(172, 168, 175, 170, 180, 165, 178, 172, 169, 176)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: result_bs <- bs_mean(heights, R = 1000, conf = 0.95) cat(“Sample mean:”, round(result_bs$stat, 2), "\n") cat("95% CI:", round(result_bs$ci, 2), “”, round(result_bs$ci, 2), “”)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: result_bca <- bca_ci(heights, R = 1000, conf = 0.95) cat(“BCa CI lower bound:”, round(result_bca$ci, 2), "\n") cat("BCa CI upper bound:", round(result_bca$ci, 2), “”) Key difference: BCa accurate skewed distributions.

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: Use moving_block_boot() stationary_boot() : - data temporal dependence (autocorrelation) - Standard IID bootstrap invalid - Examples: stock prices, climate data, economic time series Example: Moving block bootstrap AR(1) process {r timeseries-example} # Generate AR(1) time series ts_data <- arima.sim(n = 100, list(ar = 0.7), sd = 1)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: boot_samples <- moving_block_boot(ts_data, block_size = 10, R = 200)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: bootstrap_means <- sapply(boot_samples, mean)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: cat(“Original mean:”, round(mean(ts_data), 3), “”) cat(“Bootstrap mean (average):”, round(mean(bootstrap_means), 3), “”) cat(“Bootstrap SE:”, round(sd(bootstrap_means), 3), “”) Choosing block size: Use block_size ≈ √n rule thumb.

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: Use wild_boot_lm() : - ’re fitting linear regression heteroscedasticity - Residuals non-constant variance - want robust inference coefficients Example: Wild bootstrap heteroscedastic regression {r wild-boot-example} # Generate heteroscedastic data set.seed(42) x <- seq(-2, 2, length = 50) y <- 2 + 1.5 * x + rnorm(50, sd = abs(x) * 0.5) # Variance depends x

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: fit <- lm(y ~ x)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: wb_result <- wild_boot_lm(fit, R = 1000, type = “rademacher”) cat(“Intercept estimate:”, round(wb_result$coef, 3), "\n") cat("Slope estimate:", round(wb_result$coef, 3), “”)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: ci_slope <- quantile(wb_result$boot[2, ], probs = c(0.025, 0.975)) cat(“95% CI slope:”, round(ci_slope, 3), “”, round(ci_slope, 3), “”) Weight schemes: - Rademacher: ±1 equal probability (faster, robust) - Mammen: Empirically calibrated distribution (asymptotically optimal)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: Use perm_test_2sample() : - Comparing two independent groups - Avoiding parametric assumptions - Data small non-normal Example: Two-sample permutation test {r perm-test-example} # Group : untreated group_a <- c(2.3, 4.1, 3.7, 2.9, 4.5, 3.2)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: perm_result <- perm_test_2sample(group_a, group_b, R = 5000) cat(“Mean Group :”, round(mean(group_a), 2), “”) cat(“Mean Group B:”, round(mean(group_b), 2), “”) cat(“Difference:”, round(perm_result$obs, 2), "\n") cat("Two-sided p-value:", round(perm_result$p.value, 4), “”) Interpretation: p-value < 0.05, evidence significant group difference.

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: Use perm_maxT() : - Testing multiple variables/features simultaneously - Need control family-wise error rate (FWER) - Examples: genomics, fMRI, survey data Example: Permutation maxT multiple testing {r perm-maxT-example} # Simulate gene expression data: 30 genes, 2 groups set.seed(42) data <- matrix(rnorm(600), nrow = 50, ncol = 12) # 50 obs, 12 variables groups <- rep(0:1, = 25)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: data[1:25, 3] <- data[1:25, 3] + 1.5 # Group effect

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: maxT_result <- perm_maxT(data, groups, R = 1000)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: cat(“Number variables:”, length(maxT_result$p.values), "\n") cat("FWER-adjusted p-values (first 5):\n") print(round(maxT_result$p.values[1:5], 4)) cat(“Variable 3 p-value:”, round(maxT_result$p.values, 4), “”) Key advantage: Maintains FWER control powerful Bonferroni.

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: Use auto_select_method() get recommendations: {r auto-select} # Example 1: IID data x_iid <- rnorm(50) rec1 <- auto_select_method(x_iid) cat(“IID data recommendation:”, rec1$method, “”)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: ts <- arima.sim(n = 100, list(ar = 0.8)) rec2 <- auto_select_method(ts) cat(“Time series recommendation:”, rec2$method, “”)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: mat <- matrix(rnorm(300), nrow = 50, ncol = 6) rec3 <- auto_select_method(mat) cat(“Multivariate recommendation:”, rec3$method, “”)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: extreme quantiles skewed distributions, use studentized_ci(): {r studentized-example} # Right-skewed data (exponential) data_skewed <- rexp(100, rate = 0.5)

what: vs. Studentized CI (more accurate for skewed data)
title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: ci_studentized <- studentized_ci(data_skewed, q = 0.5, R = 500, Rinner = 100) cat(“Studentized 95% CI median:”) cat(“Lower:”, round(ci_studentized, 2), “”) cat(“Upper:”, round(ci_studentized, 2), “”)

previous_headings: vs. Studentized CI (more accurate for skewed data)
title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: Compare bootstrap methods data known distribution: {r sim-example, eval = FALSE} # Define data generator generator <- function() { # Sample mixture two normals (bimodal) component <- sample(1:2, size = 50, replace = TRUE, prob = c(0.6, 0.4)) ifelse(component == 1, rnorm(50, mean = -2, sd = 1), rnorm(50, mean = 3, sd = 1) ) }

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: sim_results <- compare_methods_sim( data_generator = generator, Rsim = 50, # 50 simulated datasets Rboot = 1000, # 1000 bootstrap replicates parallel = TRUE # Use parallelization )

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: coverage_bs <- mean(sapply(sim_results, function(res) { (.list(res$bs)) {     # Check true mean (-2 3 range) CI     res$bs$ci <= 0.5 && 0.5 <= res$bs$ci } else { FALSE } })) cat(“Bootstrap coverage:”, round(coverage_bs, 3), “”)

previous_headings: Analyze coverage > Best Practices for Publication
what: 1. Report Both Point Estimate and CI
title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: {r} result <- bs_mean(rnorm(50), R = 5000) # Report: Mean = X (95% CI: [, B])

previous_headings: Analyze coverage > Best Practices for Publication
title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: Plot data choosing method time series, examine ACF plots regression, check residual plots heteroscedasticity

previous_headings: Analyze coverage > Best Practices for Publication
title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: R = 2000 quick exploratory analysis R = 5000 publication-quality results R = 10000 extremely skewed distributions

previous_headings: Analyze coverage > Best Practices for Publication
title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: methods section: > “computed 95% confidence intervals using moving block bootstrap block size = 15 account temporal autocorrelation time series.”

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: default, modernBoot functions use sequential computation. faster results large datasets: {r, eval = FALSE} library(future)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: plan(multisession, workers = 4)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: result <- bs_mean(large_data, R = 10000)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: plan(sequential)

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: ❌ Using standard bootstrap dependent data → Use block stationary bootstrap ❌ Ignoring heteroscedasticity regression → Use wild bootstrap ❌ R small → CI may unstable, use R ≥ 2000 ❌ Multiple testing without correction → Use permutation maxT ✅ use auto_select_method() unsure → helps guide choice

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: Efron, B., & Tibshirani, R. J. (1993). introduction bootstrap. Chapman Hall/CRC. Politis, D. N., & Romano, J. P. (1994). stationary bootstrap. Journal American Statistical Association, 89(428), 1303-1313. Wu, C. F. (1986). Jackknife, bootstrap resampling methods regression analysis. Annals Statistics, 14(4), 1261-1295.

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: {r, eval = FALSE} # See functions ?modernBoot

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: ?bs_mean ?wild_boot_lm ?perm_test_2sample

title: Method Selection and Practical Examples
text: vignette(“method-selection”)

code: @Manual{,   title = {modernBoot: Modern Resampling Methods: Bootstraps, Wild, Block, Permutation, and Selection Guidance},   author = {Ibrahim Kholil Rakib},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://github.com/ikrakib/modernBoot}, }

title: Automatic Resampling Method Selection — auto_select_method
text: Inspects data structure recommends appropriate resampling method.

title: Automatic Resampling Method Selection — auto_select_method
text: data numeric vector, matrix, time series object representing data analyze. vectors: univariate sample. matrices/data.frames: multivariate data rows=observations, columns=variables. ts objects: automatically detected time series. cluster optional vector cluster IDs (integer factor). Length must equal nrow(data) matrices length(data) vectors. Identifies hierarchical grouping (e.g., repeated measures within subjects, multiple samples source). NULL (default), clustering considered. provided, triggers clustered bootstrap recommendation.

title: Automatic Resampling Method Selection — auto_select_method
text: list two character string elements: method recommended resampling method name. Values:     "clustered_boot" (cluster provided),     "block_boot" (time series detected),     "perm_maxT" (multivariate matrix detected),     "nonparametric_boot" (default IID univariate data) rationale human-readable explanation recommendation.     Describes chosen method appropriate structure     data exhibits.

title: Automatic Resampling Method Selection — auto_select_method
text: Decision logic: - clusters provided: use clustered bootstrap - time series detected: use block stationary bootstrap - multivariate matrix: use permutation maxT - Otherwise (IID data): use standard nonparametric bootstrap

title: Automatic Resampling Method Selection — auto_select_method
code: # IID data x <- rnorm(50) auto_select_method(x) #> $method #> [1] "nonparametric_boot" #>  #> $rationale #> [1] "IID univariate data detected; use standard nonparametric bootstrap (bs_mean, bca_ci, etc.)." #>   # Time series ts_data <- arima.sim(n = 100, list(ar = 0.7)) auto_select_method(ts_data) #> $method #> [1] "block_boot" #>  #> $rationale #> [1] "Time series structure detected; use block or stationary bootstrap to preserve temporal dependence." #>

what: Bias-Corrected and Accelerated (BCa) Bootstrap Confidence Interval — bca_ci
title: Bias-Corrected and Accelerated (BCa) Bootstrap Confidence Interval — bca_ci
text: Computes BCa confidence interval mean using boot package.

title: Bias-Corrected and Accelerated (BCa) Bootstrap Confidence Interval — bca_ci
Bias-Corrected and Accelerated (BCa) Bootstrap Confidence Interval — bca_ci
text: x numeric vector data. R integer number bootstrap replicates (default 2000). conf numeric confidence level 0 1 (default 0.95).

title: Bias-Corrected and Accelerated (BCa) Bootstrap Confidence Interval — bca_ci
text: list elements boot (object) ci (matrix).

title: Bias-Corrected and Accelerated (BCa) Bootstrap Confidence Interval — bca_ci

what: Nonparametric Bootstrap Confidence Interval for the Mean — bs_mean
title: Nonparametric Bootstrap Confidence Interval for the Mean — bs_mean
text: Compute bootstrap distribution sample mean.

title: Nonparametric Bootstrap Confidence Interval for the Mean — bs_mean
Nonparametric Bootstrap Confidence Interval for the Mean — bs_mean
text: x numeric vector data. R integer number bootstrap replicates (default 2000). conf numeric confidence level 0 1 (default 0.95).

title: Nonparametric Bootstrap Confidence Interval for the Mean — bs_mean
text: list elements stat (mean), boot (replicates), ci (interval).

title: Nonparametric Bootstrap Confidence Interval for the Mean — bs_mean
code: set.seed(42) x <- rnorm(50, mean = 5, sd = 2) result <- bs_mean(x, R = 500) result$ci #>     2.5%    97.5%  #> 4.290905 5.527923

what: Simulation Study: Compare Bootstrap Methods — compare_methods_sim
title: Simulation Study: Compare Bootstrap Methods — compare_methods_sim
text: Runs simulation study comparing different bootstrap permutation methods. Useful empirical evaluation method performance coverage.

title: Simulation Study: Compare Bootstrap Methods — compare_methods_sim
Simulation Study: Compare Bootstrap Methods — compare_methods_sim
text: data_generator function taking arguments returning numeric vector data. Called Rsim times generate independent datasets. Example: function() rnorm(50, mean=5, sd=2) generates normal data. Function must side effects; deterministic given seed. Rsim integer number simulated datasets generate (default 100). Larger values (500+) provide stable coverage rate estimates increase computation time. simulation applies bs_mean bca_ci methods independently. Must >= 1. Rboot integer number bootstrap replicates used within method per dataset (default 1000). Matches R parameter passed bs_mean bca_ci. Larger values (2000-5000) improve interval accuracy increase total computation (total bootstrap samples = Rsim * Rboot). Must >= 1. parallel logical enable parallel computation across simulations (default TRUE). Uses multisession plan distribute simulations across available cores. User can override plan(future::sequential) calling sequential execution.

title: Simulation Study: Compare Bootstrap Methods — compare_methods_sim
text: list length Rsim. element list two components: bs result bs_mean applied simulated dataset.     NA generation computation failed. bca result bca_ci applied dataset.     NA generation computation failed. Use assess coverage rates: true parameter fall within returned CIs?   Interval width variation indicates method stability.

title: Simulation Study: Compare Bootstrap Methods — compare_methods_sim
text: function repeatedly generates data data_generator applies bs_mean bca_ci methods. Results can used study coverage rates, interval width, method robustness.

title: Simulation Study: Compare Bootstrap Methods — compare_methods_sim
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(42) # Simulate from normal distribution generator <- function() rnorm(50, mean = 5, sd = 2) sim_results <- compare_methods_sim(generator, Rsim = 50, Rboot = 500)  # Analyze coverage: does true mean (5) fall in each CI? coverage_bs <- mean(sapply(sim_results, function(res) {   res$bs$ci[1] <= 5 && 5 <= res$bs$ci[2] })) coverage_bs #> [1] 0.94 # }

what: Moving Block Bootstrap for Time Series — moving_block_boot
title: Moving Block Bootstrap for Time Series — moving_block_boot
text: Performs moving block bootstrap resampling dependent data (time series). Preserves temporal dependence structure within blocks.

title: Moving Block Bootstrap for Time Series — moving_block_boot
Moving Block Bootstrap for Time Series — moving_block_boot
text: x numeric vector time series object. univariate time series temporal dependence (autocorrelation). using ts object, inherits frequency information. Length n >= block_size required. block_size integer length consecutive observations keep together bootstrap samples (default 10). Rule thumb: approximately sqrt(n) n series length. Must >= 1 <= length(x). Larger blocks preserve longer-range dependence; smaller blocks reduce distortion may capture autocorrelation structure. R integer number bootstrap replicates (default 1000). replicate complete time series length n obtained concatenating randomly selected blocks. Must >= 1.

title: Moving Block Bootstrap for Time Series — moving_block_boot
text: list length R. element numeric vector length n   (original series length), representing one bootstrap replicate   time series. Replicates preserve block structure local dependence   within blocks, though global autocorrelation structure may altered.

title: Moving Block Bootstrap for Time Series — moving_block_boot
text: moving block bootstrap divides time series overlapping blocks length block_size resamples blocks replacement. preserves short-range dependence allowing empirical sampling distribution reflect dependence.

title: Moving Block Bootstrap for Time Series — moving_block_boot
code: set.seed(42) x <- arima.sim(n = 100, list(ar = 0.7)) result <- moving_block_boot(x, block_size = 10, R = 100) length(result)  # 100 bootstrap replicates #> [1] 100

what: Permutation maxT for Multiple Testing — perm_maxT
title: Permutation maxT for Multiple Testing — perm_maxT
text: Performs permutation-based multiple testing correction using maxT method. Controls family-wise error rate (FWER) testing multiple hypotheses.

title: Permutation maxT for Multiple Testing — perm_maxT
Permutation maxT for Multiple Testing — perm_maxT
text: data_matrix numeric matrix dimensions (n x p) n = number observations (samples), p = number variables (features/genes/voxels). Rows observations, columns variables. NAs allowed; remove impute calling. Example: gene expression matrix n = 50 samples, p = 10000 genes. groups factor vector group labels (length n). exactly 2 unique levels representing group membership. Numeric (0/1) character ("control"/"treatment") acceptable. Order corresponds data_matrix rows. R integer number permutation replicates (default 2000). Larger values (5000-10000) recommended stable p-values. Computational cost scales linearly R. Must >= 1.

title: Permutation maxT for Multiple Testing — perm_maxT
text: list two elements: obs numeric vector length p, observed t-statistics variable.     Positive/negative values indicate direction difference. Names preserved     column names data_matrix present. p.values numeric vector length p, FWER-adjusted p-values.     Computed proportion permutation replicates     max(|t_permuted|) >= |t_observed|. Controls family-wise error rate level     approximately R/(R+1). Values automatically sorted match obs vector.

title: Permutation maxT for Multiple Testing — perm_maxT
text: maxT method conducts individual t-tests variable, corrects multiple comparisons using distribution maximum absolute t-statistic permutation. maintains FWER specified level preserving power.

title: Permutation maxT for Multiple Testing — perm_maxT
code: set.seed(42) data <- matrix(rnorm(200), nrow = 50, ncol = 4) groups <- rep(0:1, each = 25) result <- perm_maxT(data, groups, R = 500) result$p.values #> [1] 1 1 1 1

title: Two-Sample Permutation Test — perm_test_2sample
text: Performs exact approximate permutation test comparing two independent samples. Tests null hypothesis two groups equal distributions.

title: Two-Sample Permutation Test — perm_test_2sample
code: perm_test_2sample(x, y, R = 5000, stat = function(a, b) mean(a) - mean(b))

title: Two-Sample Permutation Test — perm_test_2sample
text: x numeric vector, first sample (group ). May contain NAs removed. Minimum 2 observations required. Length need equal length(y). y numeric vector, second sample (group B). May contain NAs removed. Minimum 2 observations required. Compared x differences. R integer number permutation replicates (default 5000). Larger values (e.g., 10000) improve p-value accuracy. Must >= 1. Exact test feasible R = C(n1+n2, n1) (factorial complexity), otherwise uses approximate permutation distribution. stat function taking two arguments (, b) returning numeric scalar test statistic. Default: function(, b) mean() - mean(b) tests difference means. Alternative: function(, b) median() - median(b) medians, custom statistics. Function must handle NAs gracefully.

title: Two-Sample Permutation Test — perm_test_2sample
text: list three elements: obs numeric scalar, observed test statistic computed original data reps numeric vector length R, test statistics random     permutations group labels. Represents null distribution assuming     equal distributions groups. p.value numeric scalar 0 1, two-sided p-value computed     proportion permutation replicates |stat| >= |obs|. Value 1/R     smallest achievable p-value.

title: Two-Sample Permutation Test — perm_test_2sample
text: null hypothesis equal distributions, exchanging group labels equally likely. p-value proportion permutations test statistic least extreme observed (absolute value).

title: Two-Sample Permutation Test — perm_test_2sample
code: set.seed(42) group1 <- rnorm(20, mean = 0) group2 <- rnorm(20, mean = 0.5) result <- perm_test_2sample(group1, group2, R = 1000) result$p.value #> [1] 0.932

title: Stationary Bootstrap (Politis & Romano) — stationary_boot
text: Performs stationary bootstrap dependent data random block lengths. flexible fixed-block bootstrap time series variable dependence.

title: Stationary Bootstrap (Politis & Romano) — stationary_boot
text: x numeric vector time series object. univariate time series temporal dependence. Length n >= 2 required. ts object, frequency information preserved output. p numeric probability parameter controlling average block length (default 0.1). Must satisfy 0 < p <= 1. Average block length approximately 1/p: set p = 0.1 average blocks ~10 observations, p = 0.05 ~20 observations. Smaller p values preserve longer-range dependence; larger p values reduce distortion. R integer number bootstrap replicates (default 1000). replicate complete time series length n random block structure. Must >= 1.

title: Stationary Bootstrap (Politis & Romano) — stationary_boot
text: list length R. element numeric vector length n   (matching original series). Unlike moving block bootstrap, block lengths   vary randomly following geometric distribution, avoiding artificial   periodicity. Replicates preserve local dependence structure flexibly   fixed-block methods.

title: Stationary Bootstrap (Politis & Romano) — stationary_boot
text: stationary bootstrap uses random block lengths drawn geometric distribution. avoids artificial periodicity inherent fixed-block methods. Set p = 1/m average block length approximately m.

title: Stationary Bootstrap (Politis & Romano) — stationary_boot
code: set.seed(42) x <- arima.sim(n = 100, list(ar = 0.7)) # Average block length of 10: p = 0.1 result <- stationary_boot(x, p = 0.1, R = 100) length(result)  # 100 bootstrap replicates #> [1] 100

what: Studentized Bootstrap Confidence Interval for Quantiles — studentized_ci
title: Studentized Bootstrap Confidence Interval for Quantiles — studentized_ci
text: Computes studentized (t-based) bootstrap confidence interval quantiles. accurate percentile intervals, especially extreme quantiles.

title: Studentized Bootstrap Confidence Interval for Quantiles — studentized_ci
Studentized Bootstrap Confidence Interval for Quantiles — studentized_ci
text: x numeric vector data. May contain NAs removed. Minimum 2 observations required. Works well skewed distributions extreme quantiles percentile bootstrap performs poorly. q numeric quantile level 0 1 (default 0.5 median). 0.25 = first quartile, 0.75 = third quartile, 0.95 = 95th percentile. Method particularly effective extreme quantiles (q < 0.1 q > 0.9). R integer number outer bootstrap replicates (default 1000). primary bootstrap sample t-distribution estimation. Recommended: 500-1000 exploration, 2000+ publication. Must >= 1. Rinner integer number inner bootstrap replicates standard error estimation outer replicate (default 200). Larger values increase accuracy also computation time (total iterations = R * Rinner). Recommended: 100-200. Must >= 1. conf numeric confidence level 0 1 (default 0.95). Standard: 0.95 0.99. Higher values give wider intervals.

title: Studentized Bootstrap Confidence Interval for Quantiles — studentized_ci
text: numeric vector length 2 names c("lower", "upper"): lower numeric, lower confidence limit q-th quantile upper numeric, upper confidence limit q-th quantile Uses studentized bootstrap t-distribution construct interval,   providing better coverage probability percentile method,   especially skewed distributions extreme quantiles.

title: Studentized Bootstrap Confidence Interval for Quantiles — studentized_ci
text: Studentized bootstrap uses bootstrap t-distribution construct intervals. method often provides better coverage percentile bootstrap, especially skewed distributions extreme quantiles. Computation intensive: O(R * Rinner) bootstrap samples generated.

title: Studentized Bootstrap Confidence Interval for Quantiles — studentized_ci
code: set.seed(42) x <- rexp(50)  # right-skewed distribution ci <- studentized_ci(x, q = 0.75, R = 500, Rinner = 100) ci #>    lower    upper  #> 1.072874 1.483589

what: Wild Bootstrap for Linear Model Coefficients — wild_boot_lm
title: Wild Bootstrap for Linear Model Coefficients — wild_boot_lm
text: Performs wild bootstrap resampling linear regression models handle heteroscedasticity. Supports Rademacher Mammen weight schemes.

title: Wild Bootstrap for Linear Model Coefficients — wild_boot_lm
Wild Bootstrap for Linear Model Coefficients — wild_boot_lm
text: fit object class 'lm' lm. fitted linear regression model. Heteroscedasticity allowed expected - method specifically designed handle non-constant variance residuals. Model least 1 predictor. R integer number bootstrap replicates (default 2000). Larger values (5000-10000) recommended confidence intervals publications. Must >= 1 whole number. type character string specifying weight distribution scheme. Options: "rademacher" (default, faster, robust) generates weights +1/-1 equal probability. "mammen" (asymptotically optimal) uses empirically calibrated Mammen distribution golden ratio. Choice minimal practical impact results.

title: Wild Bootstrap for Linear Model Coefficients — wild_boot_lm
text: list two elements: coef numeric vector original fitted model coefficients,     including intercept present. Names preserved original model. boot numeric matrix dimensions (p x R) p number     coefficients. column contains one bootstrap replicate coefficients.     Row names coefficient names; column names bootstrap iteration numbers.

title: Wild Bootstrap for Linear Model Coefficients — wild_boot_lm
text: wild bootstrap works resampling residuals random signs/weights keeping predictors fixed. particularly useful heteroscedastic data.

title: Wild Bootstrap for Linear Model Coefficients — wild_boot_lm
modernBoot 0.1.0
text: Initial release modernBoot package core resampling methods Bootstrap methods: bs_mean(), bca_ci(), studentized_ci() confidence intervals Wild bootstrap: wild_boot_lm() heteroscedastic linear models Rademacher Mammen weights Block bootstrap: moving_block_boot() stationary_boot() dependent time series data Permutation tests: perm_test_2sample() two-sample inference Multiple testing correction: perm_maxT() controlling family-wise error rate Automated method selection: auto_select_method() intelligently recommends resampling approach based data structure Simulation tools: compare_methods_sim() benchmarking different resampling methods Parallel computation: Full support future package parallelization (user-controlled)

title: modernBoot 0.1.0
text: bs_mean() — Nonparametric bootstrap confidence interval mean (percentile method) bca_ci() — Bias-corrected accelerated (BCa) bootstrap confidence interval studentized_ci() — Studentized bootstrap confidence interval quantiles

title: modernBoot 0.1.0
text: moving_block_boot() — Moving block bootstrap time series stationary_boot() — Stationary bootstrap (Politis & Romano, 1994)

title: modernBoot 0.1.0
text: wild_boot_lm() — Wild bootstrap linear regression heteroscedasticity

title: modernBoot 0.1.0
text: perm_test_2sample() — Two-sample permutation test perm_maxT() — Permutation maxT multiple hypothesis testing FWER control

title: modernBoot 0.1.0
text: auto_select_method() — Automatic resampling method selection compare_methods_sim() — Simulation comparison bootstrap methods Internal helpers: check_numeric_vector(), .safe_sample()

title: modernBoot 0.1.0
text: Imports: stats, utils, boot, future, future.apply Suggests: testthat, covr, pkgdown, knitr, rmarkdown, rhub Requires: R ≥ 4.0
